name: Sigurd
subtitle: Greatest Hero of the North - Slayer of Fafnir
description: Sigurd (Old Norse: Sigurðr; Middle High German: Siegfried) was the supreme hero of Germanic and Norse legend, the dragon-slayer par excellence. Descended from Odin through the Volsung line, he was raised by the cunning dwarf Regin, who forged for him the sword Gram and set him against the dragon Fafnir—once a dwarf, transformed by greed into a monstrous serpent guarding cursed gold. Sigurd's victory made him seemingly invincible (bathed in dragon blood) yet doomed by the cursed treasure he claimed. His tragic love for the valkyrie Brynhild, forgotten through a magic potion, led to betrayal and death. His story, preserved in the Volsunga Saga and Poetic Edda, became the foundation for the medieval Nibelungenlied and Wagner's Ring Cycle.

parentage.divine: Odin - Divine ancestor of the Volsung line
parentage.mortal: Sigmund - Father, greatest warrior of his age, killed before Sigurd's birth; Hjordis - Mother, remarried to King Alf
parentage.heritage: Last of the Volsung dynasty, descended from Odin

parents.father: Sigmund (son of Volsung, grandson of Odin)

family.wife: Gudrun (daughter of Gjuki, given by magic potion)

weapons: Gram - The legendary sword, shattered by Odin and reforged by Regin, capable of splitting an anvil
Dragon-blood invulnerability - Made his skin impervious except where a linden leaf fell

keyMyths.title: The Reforging of Gram
keyMyths.description: The sword Gram had belonged to Sigurd's father Sigmund, shattered by Odin when Sigmund's time came. The dwarf Regin reforged it for Sigurd, who tested it by splitting Regin's anvil in two and cutting through a tuft of wool floating downstream.

keyMyths.title: The Slaying of Fafnir
keyMyths.description: Regin (Fafnir's brother) sent Sigurd to kill the dragon and claim the cursed gold. Following Odin's disguised advice, Sigurd dug a pit on the path to Fafnir's watering hole. When the dragon passed over, Sigurd thrust Gram up into its heart. Fafnir, dying, warned Sigurd of the curse on the gold.

keyMyths.title: Tasting the Dragon's Blood
keyMyths.description: While roasting Fafnir's heart for Regin, Sigurd touched the blood to test if it was done, burning his finger. When he put his finger to his mouth, he suddenly understood bird speech. Birds warned him that Regin planned to betray and kill him. Sigurd struck off Regin's head.

keyMyths.title: Awakening Brynhild
keyMyths.description: Sigurd rode to Hindarfjall, where a ring of fire surrounded a sleeping figure in armor. He rode through the flames, cut away the armor, and found the valkyrie Brynhild, put to sleep by Odin for disobedience. They exchanged vows and the ring Andvaranaut, but fate would tear them apart.

keyMyths.title: The Potion of Forgetfulness
keyMyths.description: At the court of King Gjuki, Queen Grimhild gave Sigurd a magic potion that made him forget Brynhild. He married Grimhild's daughter Gudrun. Later, in Gunnar's shape, he rode through the flames again to win Brynhild for Gunnar—a deception that would destroy them all.

keyMyths.title: Death and the Funeral Pyre
keyMyths.description: When the deception was revealed, Brynhild goaded Gunnar and Guttorm to murder Sigurd. He was killed in bed (or the forest, in some versions), the curse of the gold fulfilled. Brynhild, realizing her love, killed herself on Sigurd's funeral pyre, asking to be burned beside him.

heroJourney.callToAdventure: Regin's manipulation to claim the dragon gold
heroJourney.supernaturalAid: Odin's disguised guidance; Regin's forging of Gram
heroJourney.thresholdCrossing: Slaying Fafnir and claiming the cursed treasure
heroJourney.transformation: Dragon blood grants invulnerability and wisdom (bird-speech)
heroJourney.ordeal: Riding through fire to win Brynhild for another
heroJourney.tragedy: Betrayal, murder, and the fulfillment of the curse

comparativeNotes.greek: Parallels Heracles in strength, monster-slaying, and tragic death; parallels Achilles in partial invulnerability and death by treachery
comparativeNotes.nearEastern: Dragon-slaying echoes Mesopotamian and Indo-European dragon/serpent combat myths
comparativeNotes.germanic: The Nibelungenlied version (Siegfried) adds courtly elements; Wagner's Ring synthesizes all versions
comparativeNotes.christian: The dragon-slayer became a template for St. George and Christian knight-heroes

christologicalParallels.overview: Sigurd/Siegfried presented complex typological material for medieval Christian interpreters. The dragon-slayer dying through betrayal offered parallels to Christ, while the cursed gold warned against worldly attachment.
christologicalParallels.dragonSlayer: Sigurd's victory over Fafnir exemplifies the serpent-slaying motif (Genesis 3:15). Medieval readers saw dragon-slayers as types of Christ crushing Satan. The Norse serpent Fafnir, transformed by greed, represents sin's deforming power.
christologicalParallels.vulnerabilityAndDeath: Like Achilles (heel) and Christ (chosen mortality), Sigurd has one vulnerable point—where a linden leaf fell during his blood-bath. He is killed through betrayal by those closest to him, as Christ was betrayed by Judas.
christologicalParallels.cursedTreasure: The gold of Fafnir carries Andvari's curse—all who possess it are destroyed. This parallels the biblical warning that 'the love of money is the root of all evil' (1 Timothy 6:10). Sigurd, despite his wisdom, cannot escape the curse.
christologicalParallels.baptismImagery: Sigurd's bathing in dragon blood for invulnerability inverts Christian baptism—blood conferring earthly power rather than water conferring spiritual life. The one vulnerable spot shows the insufficiency of all earthly protections.
christologicalParallels.restoredHonor: In some versions, Sigurd is mourned as one who will return or whose spirit endures. The Volsung dynasty ends with him, but his legend lives forever—an immortality of fame, not resurrection.

patristics.medievalReception: Medieval Christian audiences read dragon-slaying legends through the lens of saints' lives (George, Michael). Sigurd became a model for the Christian knight.
patristics.wagnerianInterpretation: Wagner's Ring Cycle adds explicit redemption theology—the gods' twilight and Brunnhilde's sacrifice parallel Christian apocalypse and atonement.
patristics.moralReading: Medieval moralists read Sigurd's story as a cautionary tale about worldly attachment (the gold) versus true love (Brynhild) betrayed.

keyDistinctions: Sigurd kills the dragon for treasure; Christ overcomes Satan for humanity's salvation
Sigurd's invulnerability is physical; Christ's authority is spiritual
Sigurd is destroyed by the cursed gold; Christ redeems all curses
Sigurd forgets his true love; Christ never forgets his own
Sigurd dies permanently (in the myth); Christ rises from death

quests: Claiming the cursed treasure of Andvari
allies: Odin - Divine ancestor who guided him in disguise
Regin - Foster-father and sword-forger (before his betrayal)
enemies: Regin - Who planned to betray him after Fafnir's death
The curse of Andvaranaut - Doom on all who possess the gold
Gunnar and Guttorm - Who murdered him
abilities: Supreme warrior - unmatched in combat with the sword Gram
Near-invulnerability - bathed in dragon blood except one spot
Wisdom - understood bird-speech after tasting dragon blood
Nobility - praised for generosity and honor despite the curse
feats: Reforged and tested the sword Gram (split anvil, cut floating wool)
Slew the dragon Fafnir from beneath
Killed the treacherous Regin after learning bird-speech
Rode through the ring of fire to awaken Brynhild
Won Brynhild for Gunnar in Gunnar's shape
Died with such courage that his killers were shamed
sources: Volsunga Saga (13th century): The most complete Old Norse prose account of Sigurd's life.
Poetic Edda - Fáfnismál, Sigrdrífumál, Sigurðarkviða (c. 10th-13th century): Old Norse poems containing the earliest versions of the myths.
Prose Edda - Snorri Sturluson (c. 1220): References to the Volsung legends.
Nibelungenlied (c. 1200): Middle High German epic featuring Siegfried.
Thidreks Saga (13th century): Norwegian prose compilation including Sigurd material.
Richard Wagner, Der Ring des Nibelungen (1876): Operatic synthesis influencing all modern reception.
Beowulf (reference): The sword Naegling and dragon-fight echo Sigurd traditions.
modernScholarship: Jesse Byock, The Saga of the Volsungs (1990): Translation with scholarly introduction
Theodore Andersson, The Legend of Brynhild (1980): Study of the tradition's development
Carolyne Larrington, The Poetic Edda (1996/2014): Modern translation with notes
